title: AB 250
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 2290.5 of the Business and Professions Code is amended to define terms related to telemedicine, including "asynchronous store and forward" and "synchronous interaction." These definitions clarify the roles of health care providers and the locations where services are provided via telecommunications systems. Telehealth allows real-time interactions between patients and distant health care providers. Prior consent is required before using telehealth services, but patients can still opt for in-person care if needed. The section allows patients to receive in-person healthcare services after agreeing to telehealth services. Non-compliance by healthcare providers is considered unprofessional conduct. It does not change the scope of practice for healthcare providers or allow services in unauthorized settings. Confidentiality laws apply to telehealth interactions. It does not apply to patients under correctional facility jurisdiction. The section allows hospitals to grant privileges and verify credentials for providers of telehealth services based on medical staff recommendations. Telehealth includes telemedicine as defined in federal regulations. Section 4980.43 of the Business and Professions Code is amended to require applicants to complete 3,000 hours of supervised experience over 104 weeks for licensure examinations. This experience must include 1,700 hours post-qualifying degree and not more than 1,300 hours pre-degree. Applicants must complete 3,000 hours of supervised experience over 104 weeks for licensure examinations, with 1,700 hours post-qualifying degree and up to 1,300 hours pre-degree. Certain restrictions apply to the timing and types of experience hours that can be counted towards licensure. Applicants must complete 3,000 hours of supervised experience over 104 weeks for licensure examinations, with restrictions on the types of experience hours. This includes participation in personal psychotherapy, group therapy, administering psychological tests, client advocacy, diagnosing and treating couples, families, and children, and providing counseling services via telehealth. Not more than 375 hours of experience providing personal psychotherapy, crisis counseling, or other counseling services via telehealth, with a focus on working with elders and dependent adults with limitations. This requirement applies to hours gained on and after January 1, 2010. All applicants, trainees, and registrants must be supervised by a qualified supervisor to ensure counseling is appropriate. Experience must be gained as an employee or volunteer, not as an independent contractor. Interns must provide W-2 forms or a letter from their employer when applying for licensure. An intern applying for licensure must provide a letter from their employer verifying their volunteer status. Supervision requirements include one hour of direct supervisor contact per week for every five hours of client contact, with additional contact for those with more than 10 hours of client contact. Face-to-face contact can be individual or group-based. For licensure, interns need one hour of direct supervisor contact per week for every five hours of client contact, either individually or in groups of up to eight. Supervision can be done via video conferencing in certain settings. All trainee experience must be monitored by the supervisor as per regulations. The six hours of supervision that can be credited in a week apply to hours gained after January 1, 2009. Trainees can gain supervised experience in settings providing mental health counseling, overseen to meet requirements, not owned by certain licensed professionals. Interns can also gain supervised experience in settings providing mental health counseling. An intern can gain supervised experience in settings providing mental health counseling, overseen to meet requirements and within the scope of practice. They should not work in a private practice until registered. Employers are encouraged to provide fair remuneration to interns. Interns, whether paid or volunteers, should receive fair remuneration. In private practice, interns must be supervised by a licensee who meets specific requirements. Experience gained by interns should be related to their position. Registration as an intern is necessary for postdegree supervised experience hours towards licensure. All individuals must register as interns with the board to receive credit for postdegree supervised experience towards licensure, except when working in a private practice. Postdegree experience will count towards licensure if the intern applies for registration within 90 days of obtaining their qualifying degree. Trainees, interns, and applicants cannot receive payment from patients and can only be compensated by their employers. Trainees, interns, and applicants must only be paid by their employers and cannot receive remuneration from patients. They are required to perform services under the direction and control of their employer, including via telehealth if supervised by a licensed professional. Trainees and interns should not have any financial obligations to their employers. Trainees, interns, or applicants receiving up to $500 per month for expenses in work settings other than private practice are considered employees, not independent contractors. Applicants may be audited to prove expenses were incurred. Each educational institution and supervisor should consider encouraging students, interns, and trainees to undergo counseling or psychotherapy as appropriate. Assistance in locating affordable counseling services should be provided if desired by the applicant.
